Title.evidence: Wound perfusion and oxygenation are important determinants of the development of postoperative wound infections.

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned to small (n=124, 8 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) or large volume (n=129, 16-18 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) fluid management.

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned to small (n=124, 8 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) or large volume (n=129, 16-18 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) fluid management.

Intervention.evidence: Patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned to small (n=124, 8 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) or large volume (n=129, 16-18 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) fluid management.

Objective.evidence: We tested the hypothesis that supplemental fluid administration during and after elective colon resections decreases the incidence of postoperative wound infections.

Method_Outcome.evidence: All wound infections diagnosed using either criterion by a blinded observer in the 15 days following surgery were considered in the analysis.

Blinding.evidence: All wound infections diagnosed using either criterion by a blinded observer in the 15 days following surgery were considered in the analysis.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned to small (n=124, 8 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) or large volume (n=129, 16-18 mL·kg -1 ·h -1 ) fluid management.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Of the patients given small fluid administration, 14 had surgical wound infections; 11 given large fluid therapy had infections, P =0.46.
